frameDefinitions: Two (or more) people (the Parties, also encodable as Party_1 and Party_2) negotiate an agreement.
A Process stops at a certain Time and Place.
Two (or more) people (the Parties, also encodable as Party_1 and Party_2) have an agreement.
An Employee voluntarily leaves the service of an Employer.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.

An individual that is scheduled to be a Participant, or already is a Participant in an Activity or an Organization, indicates that  they will no not or no longer participate in that Activity or Organization.
frameExamples: So far , we have <t>agreed</t>to cede 100km of coastline to Kiribati . DNI
The US and Russia have an <t>agreement</t> to share early warning data on missile launches.
Leah <t>quit</t> her job after one month because of an evil force.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
The Moslem contingent had <t>withdrawn</t> from the EC talks on May 27.
listRoleDefinitions:
The individual or individuals that form the more prominent (i.e.
agentive) party of the agreement, as compared with <fen>Party_2</fen>. That is,
<fen>Party_1</fen> is generally encoded as the External Argument of verbs, and
peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself
generally make reference to <fen>Party_1</fen>. Thus <fen>Manner</fen> is construed to be that of <fen>Party_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Party_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Parties</fen> as a whole.

The semantically (and grammatically) less prominent participant (or
group of participants) in the agreement. It is generally encoded
within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with).
An expression of the commitment made by the <fen>Parties</fen> .
<fen>Topic</fen> is a description of the domain covered.
The group of individuals portrayed as equally involved in making an agreement.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the Agreement occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the Agreement occurs.
The <fen>Process</fen> which is halting.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.

The individual or individuals that form the more prominent (i.e. agentive) party of the agreement, as compared with <fen>Party_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Party_1</fen> is generally encoded as the External Argument of verbs, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Party_1</fen>. Thus <fen>Manner</fen> is construed to be that of <fen>Party_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Party_2</fen> or the group of <fen>Parties</fen> as a whole.
The semantically (and grammatically) less prominent participant (or group of participants) in the agreement. It is generally encoded within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with).
An expression of the commitment of the <fen>Parties</fen> .
<fen>Topic</fen> is a description of the domain covered by the agreement.
The group of individuals portrayed as equally involved in having an agreement.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the agreement was made.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an agreement was made.
The person who is obligated to perform some task in order to receive compensation.
The person (or institution) in whose employ  the <fen>Employee</fen> stood.
The Field that one works in.
The label given to a particular type of service that the employer quits.
This role identifies the Time when an <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The individual or individuals that are engaged or are scheduled to be engaged in an <fen>Activity</fen>.
The event that the Participant is engaged in or was scheduled to be engaged in.
The <fen>Organization</fen> is an intentionally formed human social group with some definite structure to which the <fen>Participant</fen> belongs.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Participant ends their participation in the Activity.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the Participant ends the participation in the Activity.

The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.

The robber tied <fex>Harry's ankles</fex> together.
